reviewText:
http://battlelog.co/

One of the classics (if not 'the' classic) in the BF series is definitely BF2. A little humble poll I made showed that BF2 is still close to the hearts of many, regardless if they are still playing it or not (please do vote your choice too!):

http://vote.pollcode.com/74851954

BF2's 'classic BF' gameplay set the precedence for later games in the franchise: BF 2142, BF BC2, BF3, BF4 & BF Hardline (including the now extinct free-to-play BF Play4Free and BF Heroes).

The BF2 weapons/physics is probably the most different than any other FPS. There is very little ‘visual’ recoil but the bullet deviation is more exaggerated than any FPS that I’ve played. There are hit boxes/hit detection problems, movement feels clunky etc etc (and the list goes on and on). The weapon handling is the hardest of all BFs, and also when compared to other FPSs that I play (CS/COD/ARMA franchises etc). It is not impossible to overcome the many problems to perform in-game, but it requires a steeper and longer learning curve.

Nevertheless, after describing the long list of problems above, the times when I manage to overcome all these obstacles and land kills -> the ‘high’ that I get can’t be matched by any other game.

I have about 20 FPS games (BF,COD,CS, ARMA series etc etc), and have tried new ones like BF Hardline, COD AW, COD BO3 etc, and while they are fun, the movement/weapon physics don't really feel that significantly different from each other.
The only game which movement/weapon physics feels different than the others, fresh, and stands in its own category is ironically this 10 year old game: BF2.

I played back to back BF1942, BFV, BF2, BF2142, BFBC2, BF3 and BF4 -> and personally, the hardest game for me to stop playing is BF2.

The graphics is 10 years old. But personally, I like games to look ‘realistic enough’ but don't care at all about picturesque graphics quality in today's games (especially to the extent of requiring and wasting CPU & GPU power).
Gameplay is most important, but graphics much less when determining what is fun - proof: CS 1.6 is still one of the most popular FPSs today and has many times more players than many latest pretty FPSs.

Unlike all BF games from BFBC2 onwards, BF2 has a singleplayer mode, where instead of a campaign, you can play with bots in a multiplayer setting. Any idiot knows that there is no way any bots/AI no matter how good can match human opponents, nevertheless, it is still a fun option to have especially when the internet is down.
There are tons of mods available for BF2 which gives massive amount of gameplay options and also different games. For instance, the following link show more than 200 mods available:

http://www.moddb.com/games/battlefield-2/mods

Some mods are very much more well known than others: Project Reality (which has become a standalone game), AIX 2.0, Forgotten Hope (WW2 setting), Project Alpha, and the list goes on and on. There is also a website offering advice and mods targeted on only the singleplayer aspect of the game:

http://www.battlefieldsingleplayer.com/

BF2 used to run on the Gamespy network, and since the Gamespy shut down in 2014, the BF2 community has created its own network to revive the multiplayer aspect of the game.
Either if you are revisiting a game you once played, or even a new player curious to check out why some people remain hardcore fans of the game, it is very easy to get into the BF2 action, just visit:

http://battlelog.co/

http://battlelog.co/ is a one-stop center for all your BF2 needs: multiplayer network, files, patches, technical advice, a close-knit community etc. etc.

See you in the battlefield soldier :)

After playing this game since the day of the release, the demo, and the steam version, I would like to make a true, honest review after 11 years of playing this game.
Overview This game is my favorite game of all time. With upwards of 1500 hours on this game since the demo and full game before Steam, I have yet to say any other game I have ever played comes even close to beating this game. Groundbreaking Features  Squads: Squads implement an entire new flow of gameplay PIONEERED by this game. The ability to spawn on the squad leader, and work together as a small team allows for amazing possibilities to take flags and objectives.

Commander: The commander position in this game, I feel personally, has always been aimed towards RTS players. The commander has a DIRECT outcome on the game, and has power to call in supplies, vehicle drops, and even full blown artillery strikes on enemy hardpoints to allow squads to advance.

Kits: Kits have always been big in the Battlefield franchise, but this game was when I felt it truly started to show. The addition of the Medic, Support, and Engineer has added an entire new, dynamic gameplay mechanic that allows players to choose what they would like to do in the battlefield.

Graphics: The graphics made a GIANT leap from the old, worn down Battlefield: Vietnam graphics, to groundbreaking HD gameplay that immersed players more than ever before.

reviewText:
Ah, Battlefield 2. One of the first memories I have of playing a huge multiplayer game and being gripped by it's promise of mayhem, destruction and teamwork. I even went as far as to buy a microphone so I could talk to people. TALK TO PEOPLE ON THE INTERNET!
Oh these were simpler times, before your Xbox 360s, PS3s and party chats. Before headsets were commonplace and teamwork was often done via macros, keybindings and speedy world record breaking text chat in-game to warn of an incoming squad attack. Oh those were simpler times indeed.

I'm not entirely sure if nostalgia has taken over when thinking back to Battlefield 2, but I seem to have it high up there when I think of the Battlefield series. Sure it had it's issues when it was first released, but why even care about that now, the game has since been patched and those silly little bugs have gone (and strangely reappeared in later Battlefield games - reparing while inside Armor anyone?). Yet, the concept and maps were simple and not so grand and over the top to overshadow the actual gameplay and squad based mechanics of the game (which I think can be the issue with some the maps in BF3 and BF4).

I guess if you've always been curious about the Battlefield series, but weren't sure where to begin than this game might be an OK starting point. However, you'll have to remember that this game is nearly a decade old and as such isn't going to look pretty, and it does have some very wonky mechanics, keybindings and movement issues. Yet, if you're stuck with an old machine and feel like you're missing out than BF2 should hold you over until you upgrade.
I'm pretty sure there's still an OK community of players out there too, as well as various fan patches and mods (such as Project Reality) to enhance the gameplay features and breath new life into the aging Engine.

In fact... if you DO decide BF2 is for you, please DO download Project Reality if you're looking for the ideal squad based game.

Overall Battlefield 2 has had it's moment, but it's still hanging around with a fair sized userbase considering how long it's been out. As long as you're not expecting modern levels of detail, visuals, sounds, crazy maps then I can't imagine you'd be too disappointed in BF2. If you're looking for a slower paced BF experience that relies on Teamwork then you might actually be surprised.
So that's why I'd recommend this game, as long as you know what you're looking for.

reviewText:
An absolutely amazing game and one of the last good ones in the Battlefield series alongside BF2142. I had this game since its release but decided to buy it for my Steam account so that I don't have CD's or serial keys to lose!

This game supports up to 64 players on one server so that can certainly lead to some intense combat situations, especially on the smaller maps. The infantry combat might be a tad underwhelming compared to 2142 but it still feels pretty good. I don't like how iffy movement can be but it's something that you'll forget about after some time with the game. Vehicle combat is where it's at though. Having such a large arsenal of vehicles at your disposal is a lot of fun. The only downside is that when on the larger maps you can end up being stranded for a good deal of time when you don't have a vehicle. It doesn't take that long to spawn them once they're destroyed but the problem lies when there's so many people on a server that everyone is using every available vehicle and you're miles from the AO.

If you've never played this game then I strongly suggest buying it. The mod support is absoutely fantastic. Mods such as Project Reality, AIX 2.0, and Forgotten Hope 2 bring new life to this game. So be sure to check them out on ModDB, it might do some better convincing than this review!

Hell yeah I recommend this game.
battlefield 2 is like Counter-Strike with ironsights, vehicles, medics and large-scaled maps, and also has more consequences than Battlefield 3 and 4.
For example:

- Modding the game (mods are not hacks, remember that!) forfeits your multiplayer.

reviewText:
Battlefield 2 Complete Collection is a first-person shooter game from DICE and published by EA. Battlefield 2 is a sequel from the previous Battlefield 1942.

Battlefield 2 set in modern world. Faction that are available in this game are US, Chinese, Middle East Coalition and the European Union. Battlefield 2 has improved gameplay. Teamworks has been improved a lot as now forming a squad is possible. Squad leader can call in a vehicle drop, artillery strikes or UAV recon to scout some area. A commander mode has also been introduced. Commander are responsible for giving each squad order to attack specific point, confirming squad leaders request and coordinating his team to victory. Commander mode interface is almost similar to real-time strategy game. Player can now get awards, medals and ribbon as they play, and when enough rank is achieved, a new weapon can be unlocked for each class.

Battlefield 2 has good graphics and effects. The maps on Battlefield 2 are even bigger and more detailed. Soldiers animation has also been improved a lot. The game also runs optimized with all these graphics improvements.

Battlefield 2 is a good game on its age. I recommend this.

Rating 9/10

You can still pick this up through Amazon and in second hand game bins so I'm not going to recommend legally dubious free downloads out there, even if its not for sale on Steam at the moment. It's a mystery that maybe only EA/DICE knows why they departed from the Battlefield formulae and basically trashed a recipe that had created something unique in later releases. But, frankly, *WHO CARES* ! Battlefield 2 is really still very much alive with releases still coming out from mods like Forgotten Hope - http://forgottenhope.warumdarum.de/ - and Project Reality - http://realitymod.com/ - that are both total conversions. If you still like the vanilla game play then there's plenty of player made levels out there, and even if you can't find a server then Battlefield 2 still packs a mean game in there thanks to its (still very advanced) AI bots. AI game modes can include Coop so you play with a few friends with bots included. Further Coop/SP stuff can be found here - http://battlefieldsingleplayer.com ... So still after all these years Battefield 2 could teach a lot to new game designers. I was reading another comment that pointed out that the commander mode is aimed at RTS players and it struck me that BF2 is almost a weird RTS hybrid, a bit like a Company of Heroes RTS where all those little soldiers can be played with human players. But whatever it is BF2 never fails to bring me that immersion" effect where I feel like I'm in a situation fighting for my life rather than in a video game."

Published and produced by Americas worst company of 2012: EA (Boo!) and developed by the Sweidsh folk called DICE (YAY!), Battlefield 2 was the modern version of Battlefield 1942, their first sleeper hit genre of the game franchise called... well you guessed it: Battlefield!

Battlefield 2 is extraordinarily fun with big open maps and mainly emphasis on teamwork such as passing off medkits to heal, ammo to replenish ammo and having a squad to follow or command. Become a commander of your team and lead them to victory by deploying supplies, vehicles and even bombing huge areas of the map with artillery for massive points and to help your team progress!

This game's atmosphere is really set in stone, with dreary looking outsets of what appears to be Arabic architecture to forestry and urban settings. As for the games mechanics, they are basic with some aspects of levelling involved such as Ranks which indicate how long the player has been with BF2 and his status with medals, new equipment and status. You can control absolutely every vehicle from Jets, infantry vehicles, AA gunners, deploy artillery onto areas to kill or clear the area.

Be warned that this game is NOT friendly to new players, you will find yourself dying a lot from grenade kills and generally better equipped players who had more experience. You may need to download Punkbuster to update the game manually when buying it on Steam as it will not let you play on Secure servers, it's easy to do, just download the Windows executable @ www.evenbalance.com and get the one you need (32bit)

1. Download game from Steam. Derp. Launch it and follow Steam install instructions.
2. Go to the Punkbuster website and download Punkbuster for Windows.
3. Extract pbsetup.zip and run pbsetup.exe
4. Click 'add game', select BF2 from the dropdown. Should auto detect where it's installed. Then on the main window select BF2 and select the update button. Wait for PB to update.
5. Go back to the game. Should close the first two times to open up EULA's on the web. Press ESC to skip launch intro.
6. Create an account and have fun playing! The account is different to your EA/Origin account.

I did win some medals – I was a Medic, and I’d supplement my kill count with dozens of revives on dead players. I felt pretty good about myself. I’d even lead squads, risking my neck for my men – so long as none of them were scoring higher than me.
Then, after a long and happy career, I looked at my stats page. Kills to deaths? Not good, but that’s ok, I was a Medic. Score per minute? Not good, but that’s ok, I did a lot to help my team that wasn’t always rewarded. Wins to losses? Oh. Oh God.
Apparently I acted as some kind of bad luck charm, or perhaps just a terrible-teamplay charm, because having me on your side made you about 15% less likely to win. In a 64 player game, that’s impressively bad.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing

reviewText:
***Edit - This review is based on me playing the game for the first time -  I purchased it before it was taken from the steam store but had not played it until the date of this review****

It’s like finding a corpse!

For the most part the online aspect of game is dead.  Technically there are mods, community servers and LANs which can potentially allow play with others, but EA ceased official online support a couple of years ago.

Single player offers nothing essentially.  There is no campaign.  You are dropped into a map with bots filling the roles of other players and team based objectives to complete, such as securing points.

Other than a bare loading screen description about what forces are battling and why – there isn’t any real narrative or driving story.  The match ends when points happen.

I realise that BF2 is primarily a multiplayer game but even Unreal Tournament had a contest around which to frame it’s bot matches – something that could be progressed.

Those 23 minutes of play had some tense moments, frustrations and satisfactions but since your AI teammates are morons, and your respawn points miles from the action (with no intelligent friends to pick you up in a vehicle), there is a lot of nothing happening as most of the time is spent running with just the sound of wind to keep you company.

This game has a bit of a legacy so I’m sure that the weapons and classes are balanced, that strategies and command centres are well designed, and blah blah blah… it no longer matters.  There’s just no one there to take advantage of these systems and the game can no longer be played as it was originally intended.  It’s a long abandoned, malfunctioning playground now.

Battlefield 2 isn’t even on sale any more.  So this ‘review’ is just for the very specific people in my position – those who have the game on their list and are wondering if there is anything worth their time.

There isn’t.

Possibly one of the most realistic games in the series, Battlefield 2 is an intense, action-packed military simulation with well designed maps and realistic properties such as huge maps, advanced vehicle physics and the extreme danger of being in large areas including fields, highways, deserts and large-scaled enemy bases. The game has a modernized set of weapons including the SA80, F2000, MP7 and G36C. It has a large variety of maps primarily taking place in China, but there are a large number of Middle-Eastern maps and some US maps. The highlight of this game is the extreme danger of being anywhere outside of base. The enemy is open to tons of killing machines; Tanks, APCs, Jets, Helicopters, Boats, Guns, and even Artillery cannons. It is certainly worth the money if you like intense action.
